questions.question_text: A penetration tester has been contracted to review wireless security. The tester has deployed a malicious wireless AP that mimics the configuration of the target enterprise WiFi. The penetration tester now wants to try to force nearby wireless stations to connect to the malicious AP. Which of the following steps should the tester take NEXT?

choices.D: Modify the malicious AP configuration to not use a pre-shared key.
choices.B: Perform jamming on all 2.4GHz and 5GHz channels.
choices.C: Set the malicious AP to broadcast within dynamic frequency selection channels.
choices.A: Send deauthentication frames to the stations.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A for me

comments.content:
The first step in Evil-Twin attack is to deauth the clients from the original AP/network in order to trick them into connecting to your AP, correct answer is A.
https://steemit.com/informatica/@jordiurbina1/tutorial-hacking-wi-fi-wireless-networks-with-wifislax

discussion.content:
I believe A would be the best answer in this case.
If you want the wireless stations to connect, you send deathentication requests so that on reconnecting, if your AP has a stronger signal, they will connect to that one.

I will go with A here.

Selected Answer: A
A make sense

comments.content: -A: Enable OS detection, version detection, script scanning, and traceroute

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
-A will show multiple parameters
" The only Nmap arguments used in this example are -A, to enable OS and version detection, script scanning, and traceroute; -T4 for faster execution; and then the two target hostnames."
https://manpages.org/nmap
Answer Is C

"approved version of Linux": -O
"a patched version of Apache": -sV
Since none of the options include both of these switches, -A will include OS identification (-O), service version identification (-sV), traceroute, and script scanning. Given answer is gtg.

The answer is correct. the -A flag in NMAP enables OS detection, version detection, script scanning, and traceroute. 
With OS detection, the Linux Kernel version can be determined, and since p80 has been set, the apache version can also be detected.

comments.content: A won't give you results regarding the OS running on the server, just the application version. Given answer is correct.

discussion.content: think its A. ...sV

questions.question_text: A security engineer identified a new server on the network and wants to scan the host to determine if it is running an approved version of Linux and a patched version of Apache. Which of the following commands will accomplish this task?
Which of the following expressions in Python increase a variable val by one (Choose two.)

discussion.content: It's C & F. This site explains it: https://www.prepbytes.com/blog/python/increment-operator-in-python/

Selected Answer: CF
C and F are correct

Selected Answer: CF
C F That's correct.
correct answer is C and F
++ is a no go in python. C and F.

Selected Answer: CF
The ++ operator doesn't exist in python. The += works and also adding the variable + 1 into the variable as it shows in option C

I think the answer should be C& F
https://pythonguides.com/increment-and-decrement-operators-in-python/

comments.content: AirMax is correct. Should be C and F

questions.question_text:
Given the following output:
User-agent:*
Disallow: /author/

Disallow: /xmlrpc.php -

Disallow: /wp-admin -
Disallow: /page/
During which of the following activities was this output MOST likely obtained?

discussion.content: this could be happen during domain enumeration. In exam objectives it mentions crawling websites under website reon but also shows manual inspection of web links with robots.txt under it wording makes it difficult to say which ACTIVITY it is.

Assuming they got this data from the robots.txt file - web scraping.
it is tempting to say URL enumeration, but the "disallow" aspect shows this is from a robots.txt file, which tells crawlers not to index those pages.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
The answer is correct.
Correct answer.

questions.question_text: Appending string values onto another string is called:
